content.description: Fun moves heading up and trending rightwards via a series of discontinuing crack systems with an exciting leftward traverse into a 6' right-faciing corner before the finish. Like many routes at Purina, it's kind of a sand bag, but one of the best 5.7 trad lines in the Canyon.
content.protection: Black Totem to BD #2; you probably want doubles in fingers size. Chain anchors up top.
content.location: Far right side of Purina (Purina East in the book), it's just left of the double cracks that comprise El Caliente (5.9), which it shares an anchor with. The chains are visible from ground.

climbs.name: Staring at the Sun
climbs.fa: Steve Macintosh, Dave Lenz, Viktor Krama 1989

content.description: Thin face/slab climb, not particularly memorable but worthwhile to mess around on TR after climbing Posion Ivy Crack.
content.protection: 3 bolts and chains up to (same as Poison Ivy Crack).  The two top bolts are button heads and bottom one doesn't look great either.  You can lead Poison Ivy Crack or walk around to set up TR (extend over the edge to reduce rope friction).
content.location: The route is the bolted route just to the left of Poison Ivy Crack.

content.description:
The obvious roof crack in the large alcove. Originally put up by Hugh Herr in the 80's it is unclear how much traffic the route has seen since. The hardware has been updated as of September 2019 and the route got a good scrubbing at the same time.

A mildly run out direct line exists straight up to the crack that takes small cams and nuts. Alternatively follow the corner up to the roof and then traverse right until you reach the fixed pin.
content.location:
Purina Crag central, to the right of Ordinary crack.

It's hard to miss.

content.description: Short but sweet left facing finger/layback.
content.protection:
Small-medium cams and nuts, could use a #.75, #1 or #2 before the roof.

Bolted anchor, walk off, or continue up to planet of the eights.
content.location:
All by itself behind a large Ponderosa, above a bolted boulder known as bolt rock, up and left of main trail to Careno.

As you come up the trail from dirt bike yard there is a Y in the trail near a trickle stream, go left and up to face of wall, continue left till you see obvious LFC finger crack.

content.description: Climb the crack left of Ordinary crack until you reach an obvious traverse right, continuing with the end of Ordinary Crack. Could use some cleaning.
An inviting hand crack (right of Existential Exit) ends below grassy ledges. It can get a bit waspy up there.

The crux is near the start, with some tricky pro, and opposition stemming to good cracks up higher.

There is no anchor on the Pedestal above, but you can climb the top of One Eye, also 10b through a roof to a good anchor
content.protection:
Pro to 3", save 3" cam for roof at top of One Eye.

1 bolt on One Eye

2 bolt rap anchor at top of One Eye. 100 feet to this upper anchor.
content.location:
Orange indistinct inside corner to the left of the crack of Glass Eye. Can start on left or right- near Glass Eye.

Left side is crumbly and hard to protect.

Right side, go up face left of Glass eye, turn a awkward corner left.

content.description: the bolted face is the crux, the upper trad portion is considered 10b
content.location: right of the Glass Eye crack.

content.description: This whole face can be very wet early season.
content.location:
1st route on the left side of this face past Glass Eye and the Bolted face that is One Eye.

It goes to the left side at the top to finish in a left facing corner

climbs.name: Last Call
climbs.fa: G. Briody, D. Bale, V. Kramer, 1996

content.description:
Goes to the same anchor as Late for Dinner, but finishes on the right side of the little buttress.

Can be wet and slimy in the upper crack.

This is a great route when it is dry.
content.location: right of Late for Dinner and Left of Caliente.

climbs.name: just another sucker on the vine

content.description: An interesting route that is half way up the hill above Poison Ivy crack going toward Planet of the eights. Mostly  slab with a crux step over gap. 3 bolts on route with some cams along the way
content.protection: small rack of cams, 3 bolts and 2 bolt anchor.Walk off.
content.location:
trail leads up hill from Poison Ivy, cut right at marshy stream crossing to crag on right side of trail. route starts at notch where a large boulder sits on a pedestal, with a chimney behind it. Goes up and right of boulder to step over onto slab across chimney below.

If you go inside the chimney there is a 2 bolt 10b which chimneys up to ledge.

climbs.name: Harlequin
climbs.fa: G. Daiber, M. Heath, J. Phillips, 2001

content.description:
there are two starts, left side is 10d, right is 10b, good cracks, and face climbing

Wet in the spring, dries out over the summer.
content.location: this is the where you encounter the main cliff that makes up Purina and then goes up hill to the left to Poison Ivy crack, and up hill right to Careno Crag. There is a marshy area and the route is on the black wall behind.

content.description:
I am tempted to rate this route 5.9, this may be the most sandbagged 5.8 in Leavenworth, but in keeping with the guide book it will be a good challenge for the 5.8 leader.

I don't always tape up, but this is better with tape gloves.
content.protection:
gear to 4". You may want 2 each Camalot #.5, #2, #3.

there is a bolt for the bolted face climb One Eye that you can clip up near the top

The old bolted anchor is a 20' traverse to the right and is 1/4" rusty bolts and old webbing.

You could also continue up One Eye at  the bolt to another bolt above the ledge, to hand crack through a roof to a new SS anchor ( 10b).
content.location: After passing a very large roof along the Careno trail Glass Eye stands out as the nice looking vertical hand crack that arches up to the right.

climbs.name: Existential Exit
climbs.fa: Tom Osborne, Alicia Kramar, Viktor Kramar 1989

content.description: A steep finger crack leads to a short traverse to the right, ending in a corner hand crack.

Most routes in Leavenworth are tough for the grade. This was listed as 5.9 in the book, but this one in my opinion is 5.8. Feel free to give me hell for this, curious what you think of it.

Very nice finger locks up double crack.
content.protection: gear to 2", mostly finger size. Bolted anchor, no chain, old slings.
content.location: furthest right after One Eye bolted route, closest to the water fall to it's right.

content.description: This route's start can be wet. Follow bolts upward to a delicate, airy sequence. The fun is in the surprise, how about we don't spoil it?
content.protection: Four bolts and anchor without chains.
content.location: Bolts to the right of Pat's Pillar on the tier below Ordinary Crack et al.

content.description: This would be a 3 star route if not for the dirty loose blocky start. The upper half is a stellar hand crack.I don't think it had been climbed for a long time because I cleaned a dead tree out of the crack.
content.protection:
gear to 4"

The guide book says there are anchors but I did not find them, used the anchor to the climbers right on the bolted face climb Crude Buddah to rap off.
content.location: As you come up the Careno trail and get closer to the cliff a large boulder stands by itself with a bolted line - Crack or Lieback. The left side of the boulder leads up to the base of the main cliff, Chow Time is the first on the left of a the Crude Buddah roof.

content.description:
This is a right leaning finger traverse under a big roof.

The approach maybe scares most off. an awkward tree pulling, moss holds up dirty ledges to gain start.
content.protection:
Gear to 3".  Mostly small cams for the crux. you will want a #6 camalot if you want to protect the last 15'.

No anchor.

Can rap off tree(may need webbing) or walk off to the SW.
content.location:
This is uphill from Purina.

scramble up to the left of the Black Power wall( wet seeping black face)

Obvious big roof above.

If you walk off, you may need to traverse SW and descend the Planet of the eights trail to Poison Ivy crack area.

content.description:
A neglected route that should be on any climbers tick list. Aside from the pin, all hardware was replaced April 2019.

An absolutely beautiful climb. Starts with steep jugs to a ledge rest. Fire into the crack above, clip the pin in the horizontal and commit to the boudery Crux on the steep aerete which lands you into another ledge. Clip the bolt and teeter your way up the slab finish.
content.protection: two bolts and one pin. single cams to 0.75 camalot with doubles in tips cams.
content.location: black prow left of careno crag
